record.title: PARLIAMENTARY INQUIRY
record.chair: The gentleman may state his parliamentary inquiry.

speaking-unknown-id.title: Mr.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SENSENBRENNER
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: Mr. Speaker, could the Chair tell me how many Members rose to request the recorded vote and the total number of Members present in the House upon which the Chair made his decision?

record.chair: It's up to the Chair. And let me tell you this: The vote will show that the approval would be approved by the House, as it has been.

speaking-unknown-id.title: Mr.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SENSENBRENNER
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: Mr. Speaker, does not the Constitution require that in order to get a yea and nay vote there has to be one-sixth of the Members present requesting a yea and nay vote?

speaking-unknown-id.title: Mr.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SENSENBRENNER
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: Further parliamentary inquiry. Does not a recorded vote in the House require the second of 44 Members?

record.chair: One-fifth of a quorum is required.

speaking-unknown-id.title: Mr.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SENSENBRENNER
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: Further parliamentary inquiry. Did one-fifth of the Members present stand? And, if so, how is it possible to challenge the call of the Speaker on the accuracy of the count of the Members present?

record.chair: The Chair's decision is not subject to question.

speaking-unknown-id.title: Mr.
speaking-unknown-id.name: SENSENBRENNER
speaking-unknown-id.paragraph: Mr. Speaker, I make the point of order that one-fifth of the Members present did not support the demand for a recorded vote or a yea or nay vote.

record.chair: The gentleman's point of order is not in order.
